articles.headline: A Brash Style That Filled Pews, Until Followers Had Their Fill
articles.snippet: Accused of bullying and other abuses, Mark Driscoll, a celebrity in conservative Christianity, is being urged to leave the Seattle megachurch he founded.
articles.abstract: Accused of bullying and other abuses, Mark Driscoll, a celebrity in conservative Christianity, is being urged to leave the Seattle megachurch he founded.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Mark Driscoll has long been an evangelical bad boy, a gifted orator and charismatic leader who built one of the nation’s most influential megachurches despite, or perhaps fueled by, a foul mouth, a sharp temper and frank talk about sex.

articles.headline: U.S. Finds ‘Backoff’ Hacker Tool Is Widespread
articles.snippet: The Department of Homeland Security said on Friday that more than 1,000 businesses had been infected with the cash register malware used in the Target data breach and others, leading to the theft of data from millions of customers’ payment cards.
articles.abstract: The Department of Homeland Security said on Friday that more than 1,000 businesses had been infected with the cash register malware used in the Target data breach and others, leading to the theft of data from millions of customers’ payment cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 American businesses have been affected by the cyberattack that hit the in-store cash register systems at Target, Supervalu and most recently UPS Stores, the Department of Homeland Security said in an advisory released on Friday.

articles.headline: Big Payoffs in HP Suit, for Lawyers
articles.snippet: When Hewlett shareholders sued over “unlawful behavior” in the takeover of Autonomy, they didn’t expect to be shut out in a possible settlement.
articles.abstract: When Hewlett shareholders sued over “unlawful behavior” in the takeover of Autonomy, they didn’t expect to be shut out in a possible settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: When lawyers for Hewlett-Packard shareholders filed a lawsuit contending HP’s management and board “abdicated their duties” and engaged in “unlawful behavior” in the disastrous 2011 takeover of Autonomy, it looked as if we might finally find out what really happened.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Direct Military Action Against ISIS in Syria
articles.snippet: A top national security adviser to President Obama said the United States was “not going to be restricted by borders” to protect its interests, including possibly pursuing direct military action in Syria.
articles.abstract: A top national security adviser to President Obama said the United States was “not going to be restricted by borders” to protect its interests, including possibly pursuing direct military action in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is debating a more robust intervention in Syria, including possible American airstrikes, in a significant escalation of its weeks-long military assault on the Islamic extremist group that has destabilized neighboring Iraq and killed an American journalist, officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: An Emerging Price War in the World of Investment Advice
articles.snippet: The pricing from big-name firms is particularly striking given the recent emergence of low-cost start-ups like Betterment and Wealthfront.
articles.abstract: The pricing from big-name firms is particularly striking given the recent emergence of low-cost start-ups like Betterment and Wealthfront.
articles.lead_paragraph: So let’s say you want to put all of your investments in index or exchange-traded funds, having realized that neither you nor the professionals stand much of a chance of picking stocks or mutual funds that will outperform the overall market.

articles.headline: Efforts to Revive Rich California Mine Hit Strong Resistance
articles.snippet: Where forty-niners once roamed, a plan to dig up 240,000 ounces of gold is vehemently opposed by local residents who fear damage to the environment and their way of life.
articles.abstract: Where forty-niners once roamed, a plan to dig up 240,000 ounces of gold is vehemently opposed by local residents who fear damage to the environment and their way of life.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEVADA CITY, Calif. — It is quiet at Tim Callaway’s gold mine, with its crumbling concrete, rotting wood and the occasional butterfly accustomed to undisturbed access. But there is plenty of commotion over what’s below the surface: an unseen 240,000 ounces of gold.

articles.headline: Blood Industry Shrinks as Transfusions Decline
articles.snippet: Medical advances have increased efficiency, but the trend is forcing an enormous wave of mergers and job cutbacks.
articles.abstract: Medical advances have increased efficiency, but the trend is forcing an enormous wave of mergers and job cutbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Changes in medicine have eliminated the need for millions of blood transfusions, which is good news for patients getting procedures like coronary bypasses and other procedures that once required a lot of blood.

articles.headline: Key Factor in Police Shootings: ‘Reasonable Fear’
articles.snippet: A host of outside factors, from an officer’s perception of a threat to the suspect’s behavior and even his size, can emerge as mitigating or damning.
articles.abstract: A host of outside factors, from an officer’s perception of a threat to the suspect’s behavior and even his size, can emerge as mitigating or damning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each time police officers draw their weapons, they step out of everyday law enforcement and into a rigidly defined world where written rules, hours of training and Supreme Court decisions dictate not merely when a gun can be fired, but where it is aimed, how many rounds should be squeezed off and when the shooting should stop.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Frances Robles

articles.headline: U.S. Officials and Experts at Odds on Threat Posed by ISIS
articles.snippet: With the rapid advance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the rhetoric the Obama administration is using to describe the danger the group poses to the United States has escalated.
articles.abstract: With the rapid advance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the rhetoric the Obama administration is using to describe the danger the group poses to the United States has escalated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Earlier this year, President Obama likened the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria to a junior varsity basketball squad, a group that posed little of the threat once presented by Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: An Unfinished Chapter at Countrywide
articles.snippet: Remember Angelo Mozilo, the lender’s former chief? A possible lawsuit could bring him back into the hot seat.
articles.abstract: Remember Angelo Mozilo, the lender’s former chief? A possible lawsuit could bring him back into the hot seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Angelo R. Mozilo in the cross hairs again?

articles.headline: Raising a Glass to American Upstart Distillers
articles.snippet: With a burst of new flavors and styles, boutique American whiskeys and gins are making a splash in a once-staid global market.
articles.abstract: With a burst of new flavors and styles, boutique American whiskeys and gins are making a splash in a once-staid global market.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March 2011, Michael Vachon, an American expatriate working for a struggling tech start-up business in London, was in Austin, Tex., for the South by Southwest festival, trying to drum up interest in his company.

articles.headline: Michael Bloomberg’s Harder Sell
articles.snippet: Stepping up his philanthropy, the former mayor of New York still pushes big ideas, but on a much wider stage. Turkey’s smoking rate is just one of his targets.
articles.abstract: Stepping up his philanthropy, the former mayor of New York still pushes big ideas, but on a much wider stage. Turkey’s smoking rate is just one of his targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a sweltering Saturday in June in Istanbul’s old city, Michael R. Bloomberg, power-dressed in a dark blue suit, monogrammed white shirt and cuff links, sat down to a late-morning breakfast with local antismoking activists on a rooftop overlooking the glittering Sea of Marmara.

articles.headline: Timeline for a Body: 4 Hours in the Middle of a Ferguson Street
articles.snippet: Local officials say the image of Michael Brown’s corpse in the open set the scene for what was to become a combustible worldwide story of police tactics and race in America.
articles.abstract: Local officials say the image of Michael Brown’s corpse in the open set the scene for what was to become a combustible worldwide story of police tactics and race in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Just after noon on Saturday, Aug. 9, Michael Brown was shot dead by a police officer on Canfield Drive.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: In Washington, Second Thoughts on Arming Police
articles.snippet: President Obama has ordered a comprehensive review of the government’s decade-old strategy of outfitting local police departments with military-grade body armor, officials say.
articles.abstract: President Obama has ordered a comprehensive review of the government’s decade-old strategy of outfitting local police departments with military-grade body armor, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jolted by images of protesters clashing with heavily armed police officers in Missouri, President Obama has ordered a comprehensive review of the government’s decade-old strategy of outfitting local police departments with military-grade body armor, mine-resistant trucks, silencers and automatic rifles, senior officials say.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Those Who Serve Ebola Victims Soldier On
articles.snippet: In the battle against Ebola, the front line is stitched together not only by doctors and nurses, but also by janitors, drivers and body handlers whose work puts their lives at risk.
articles.abstract: In the battle against Ebola, the front line is stitched together not only by doctors and nurses, but also by janitors, drivers and body handlers whose work puts their lives at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: KENEMA, Sierra Leone — The best defense against despair was to keep working. Many times, that choice was far from obvious: Josephine Finda Sellu lost 15 of her nurses to Ebola in rapid succession and thought about quitting herself.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Ben C. Solomon

articles.headline: For Nuncio Accused of Abuse, Dominicans Want Justice at Home, Not Abroad
articles.snippet: A top Vatican ambassador, or nuncio, was accused of child sexual abuse in the Dominican Republic, but the Vatican has stirred an outcry because it helped him avoid prosecution there.
articles.abstract: A top Vatican ambassador, or nuncio, was accused of child sexual abuse in the Dominican Republic, but the Vatican has stirred an outcry because it helped him avoid prosecution there.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — He was a familiar figure to the skinny shoeshine boys who work along the oceanfront promenade here. Wearing black track pants and a baseball cap pulled low over his balding head, they say, he would stroll along in the late afternoon and bring one of them down to the rocky shoreline or to a deserted monument for a local Catholic hero.

articles.headline: TV Chief Takes 2-by-4 to a Proposed Cable Merger
articles.snippet: Patrick Gottsch, the chairman of the Rural Media Group, has become one of the most vocal critics of Comcast’s proposed $45 billion purchase of Time Warner Cable.
articles.abstract: Patrick Gottsch, the chairman of the Rural Media Group, has become one of the most vocal critics of Comcast’s proposed $45 billion purchase of Time Warner Cable.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDINA, Minn. — As the oom-pah-pah oom-pah-pah of the band fades, Patrick Gottsch makes his way through silver-haired couples circling the dance floor at “The Mollie B Polka Party” in this quiet Midwestern town.

articles.headline: Strife in Libya Could Presage Long Civil War
articles.snippet: Libya is being torn apart by an escalating war among its patchwork of rival cities and tribes, and an assault that destroyed its main airport last month has exacerbated the nation’s divisions.
articles.abstract: Libya is being torn apart by an escalating war among its patchwork of rival cities and tribes, and an assault that destroyed its main airport last month has exacerbated the nation’s divisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — “The fire is inside the airport!” a militiaman cried, as he fired an antiaircraft cannon on the back of a pickup truck toward the runway of Libya’s main international airport. “God is great, the flames are rising!”

articles.headline: U.S. Writer Held by Qaeda Affiliate in Syria Is Freed After Nearly 2 Years
articles.snippet: Peter Theo Curtis was freed after extensive mediation by Qatar, which has negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages.
articles.abstract: Peter Theo Curtis was freed after extensive mediation by Qatar, which has negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Held for nearly two years in a prison run by an affiliate of Al Qaeda in Syria, an American freelance writer was unexpectedly freed on Sunday, following extensive mediation by Qatar, the tiny Gulf emirate and United States ally that has successfully negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages in exchange for multimillion-dollar ransoms.

articles.headline: Its Edge Intact, Vice Is Chasing Hard News
articles.snippet: Recent events suggest that Vice is deadly serious about doing real news that people, even young people, will actually watch.
articles.abstract: Recent events suggest that Vice is deadly serious about doing real news that people, even young people, will actually watch.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2010, I wrote a column about Vice in which Shane Smith, one of the founders, suggested that he and his band of insurgents were building “the next MTV.” And then there was a promise to become “the next CNN” — outrageous claims at the time, but they are becoming truer every passing day.

articles.headline: Bearing Down on Data Upstarts
articles.snippet: Box, Dropbox and Hightail are rethinking their core business models, focusing on specific industries or bolstering customer service.
articles.abstract: Box, Dropbox and Hightail are rethinking their core business models, focusing on specific industries or bolstering customer service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nothing concentrates minds at a tech start-up like living in the middle of a price war between Amazon and Google.

articles.headline: NBC News President Rouses the Network
articles.snippet: Deborah Turness convinced Matt Lauer to stay on at “Today,” is remaking “Meet the Press” and is now taking aim at the network’s digital presence.
articles.abstract: Deborah Turness convinced Matt Lauer to stay on at “Today,” is remaking “Meet the Press” and is now taking aim at the network’s digital presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: In her first year as president of NBC News, Deborah Turness received one message loud and clear: Welcome to the feeding frenzy.

articles.headline: Central Bankers’ New Gospel: Spur Jobs, Wages and Inflation
articles.snippet: The world’s central bankers made clear at an annual policy conference in Wyoming that they were focused on raising employment and wages.
articles.abstract: The world’s central bankers made clear at an annual policy conference in Wyoming that they were focused on raising employment and wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The last time the economic policy conference held here every August devoted its agenda to labor markets, it was 1994 and the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman scandalized the audience by suggesting central banks worried too much about reducing inflation and not enough about unemployment.

articles.headline: Burger King in Talks to Buy Tim Hortons and Move to Canada
articles.snippet: If completed, the deal would create one of the world’s biggest fast-food chains. It would also mean the burger giant’s headquarters would move to Canada, which has a lower corporate tax rate.
articles.abstract: If completed, the deal would create one of the world’s biggest fast-food chains. It would also mean the burger giant’s headquarters would move to Canada, which has a lower corporate tax rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Burger King may be the home of the Whopper, but Canada may be the new home of Burger King.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Medicare Star Ratings Allow Nursing Homes to Game the System
articles.snippet: Medicare’s five-year-old rating system to help families select nursing homes relies on unverified, incomplete and often misleading data.
articles.abstract: Medicare’s five-year-old rating system to help families select nursing homes relies on unverified, incomplete and often misleading data.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARMICHAEL, Calif. — The lobby of Rosewood Post-Acute Rehab, a nursing home in this Sacramento suburb, bears all the touches of a luxury hotel, including high ceilings, leather club chairs and paintings of bucolic landscapes.

articles.headline: Michael Brown Spent Last Weeks Grappling With Problems and Promise
articles.snippet: In the weeks before being fatally shot, Michael Brown, 18, due to be buried on Monday, showed signs of change and began to speak seriously about religion and the Bible, family members said.
articles.abstract: In the weeks before being fatally shot, Michael Brown, 18, due to be buried on Monday, showed signs of change and began to speak seriously about religion and the Bible, family members said.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — It was 1 a.m. and Michael Brown Jr. called his father, his voice trembling. He had seen something overpowering. In the thick gray clouds that lingered from a passing storm this past June, he made out an angel. And he saw Satan chasing the angel and the angel running into the face of God. Mr. Brown was a prankster, so his father and stepmother chuckled at first.

articles.headline: Darren Wilson Was Low-Profile Officer With Unsettled Early Days
articles.snippet: The intense focus on Officer Wilson’s actions — old and new — marked a jarring change for a man who, over most of his 28 years, had left a muted, barely noticeable trail behind.
articles.abstract: The intense focus on Officer Wilson’s actions — old and new — marked a jarring change for a man who, over most of his 28 years, had left a muted, barely noticeable trail behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — On the early afternoon of Feb. 28, 2013, Officer Darren Wilson answered a police call of a suspicious vehicle where, the police said, the occupants might have been making a drug transaction. After a struggle, Officer Wilson subdued the suspect and grabbed his car keys before help arrived, the police said.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Amid Mourning for Michael Brown, Call for Change
articles.snippet: Speakers at the teenager’s funeral service, addressing an overflowing crowd, exhorted mourners to work for justice, not just for Mr. Brown, but for others.
articles.abstract: Speakers at the teenager’s funeral service, addressing an overflowing crowd, exhorted mourners to work for justice, not just for Mr. Brown, but for others.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — His gold-and-black coffin was topped by a baseball cap — a palpable, personal reminder of the young man who was fatally shot by a police officer only weeks ago. But the calls from the pulpit were for Michael Brown’s memory to live on in a broad movement for justice, for voter participation, and for answers to vexing and unending questions about race and policing.
